BNPGrangerTestR 0.1.0

    Getting Started Installation

    Getting Started

    getting_started.Rmd
    library(BNPGrangerTestR)

    To explore the basic capabilities of BNPGrangerTestR, we’ll use the dataset example_dataset. This is a simulated sample with 200 registers and 2 continuous responses.

    BNPGrangerTestR aims to provide tools for testing the existence of a Granger causal relationship between any pair of variables, using a flexible Bayesian model.

    Fitting the model

    First, we need to train the model:

    object <-
  example_dataset |>
  bnpgrangertest()

    Testing for Granger causal relationships

    Once the model is trained, we can compute the posterior probability of each Granger causal relationship as follows:

    summarize_gamma(object)

    In this row of this tibble, cause_var is the causing variable, effect_var is the affected variable, and prob is the posterior probability of cause_var causing effect_var. In this case, there is strong evidence of a y1 (the 1st variable) Granger-causing y2 (the 2nd variable), but not the other way around.

    Computing the IRF

    In a similar, we can summarize the posterior distribution of the IRFs as follows:

    summarize_irf(object)

    In each row of this tibble, horizon is the IRF horizon, cause_var and effect_var are defined as before, irf is the posterior mean of the IRF, and lb and ub represent the 90% credible interval of the IRF.

    Computing the posterior predictive pdf

    Finally, we can summarize all (1 dimensional) posterior predictive pdfs as follows:

    summarize_pdf(object)

    In each row of this tibble, horizon is the prediction horizon, var is the target variable, y is the point for which the pdf is evaluated, and pdf is the value of the posterior predictive pdf at y.

    Plotting capabilities

    Instead of summarizying the results as a tibble, you can summarize them as a ggplot using the following functions:

    plot_gamma(object)
plot_irf(object)
plot_pdf(object)

    Extracting the MCMC chains

    Finally, you can extract the raw chains of the main variables of our model using the following functions:

    extract_chain_gamma(object)
extract_chain_irf(object)
extract_chain_pdf(object)
